title:
Norm Estimates for the Difference Between Bochner's Integral and the
  Convex Combination of Function's Values

title_detail.value:
Norm Estimates for the Difference Between Bochner's Integral and the
  Convex Combination of Function's Values

summary:
Norm estimates are developed between the Bochner integral of a vector-valued
function in Banach spaces having the Radon-Nikodym property and the convex
combination of function values taken on a division of the interval [a,b].

summary_detail.value:
Norm estimates are developed between the Bochner integral of a vector-valued
function in Banach spaces having the Radon-Nikodym property and the convex
combination of function values taken on a division of the interval [a,b].

author: S. S. Kim
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0309062v1 [math.CA] 4 Sep 2003

NORM ESTIMATES FOR THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN
BOCHNER'S INTEGRAL AND THE CONVEX COMBINATION
OF FUNCTION'S VALUES
P. CERONE, Y.J. CHO⋆ , S.S. DRAGOMIR, J.K. KIM, AND S.S. KIM
Abstract. Norm estimates are developed between the Bochner integral of
a vector-valued function in Banach spaces having the Radon-Nikodym property and the convex combination of function values taken on a division of the
interval [a, b] .

1. Introduction
A Banach space X with the property that every absolutely continuous X−valued
function is almost everywhere differentiable is said to be a Radon-Nikodym space
[7, pp. 217–219] or [2, 13] (see also [3]). For example, every reflexive Banach
space (in particular, every Hilbert space) is a Radon-Nikodym space, but the space
L∞ [0, 1] of all K−valued, essentially bounded functions defined on the interval
[0, 1], endowed with the norm
kgk∞ := ess sup |g (t)| ,
t∈[0,1]

is a Banach space which is not a Radon-Nikodym space.
A function f : [a, b] → X is measurable if there exists a sequence of simple
functions (fn ) (with fn : [a, b] → X) which converges punctually a.e. on [a, b].
It is well-known that a measurable function f : [a, b] → X is Bochner integrable
if and only if its norm, that is, the function t 7−→ kf k (t) := kf (t)k : [a, b] → X
is Lebesgue integrable on [a, b], (see for example [12]). The Bochner integral of f
Rb
shall be represented by (B) a f.
Further, we use the integration by parts formula, which holds under the following
general conditions:
Let −∞ < a < b < ∞ and f, g be two mappings defined on [a, b] such that f is
C-valued and g is X-valued, where X is a real or complex Banach space. If f, g are
differentiable on [a, b] and their derivatives are Bochner integrable on [a, b], then
Z b

For some results on the Ostrowski inequality for real-valued functions, see [1],
[5], [10] and [11], and the references therein.
The following theorem concerning a version of Ostrowski's inequality for vectorvalued functions has been obtained in [3].

1991 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 26D15; Secondary 41A55.
Key words and phrases. Bochner's Integral, Ostrowski Inequality, Quadrature Formulae

The main aim of this paper is to point out estimates between the Bochner integral of a vector-valued function, with values in Banach spaces having the RadonNikodym property and a convex combination of values taken on a given division
of the interval [a, b] . The obtained results naturally extend the Ostrowski type inequalities mentioned above. Some particular cases for two and three points rules
are also given.

Remark 1. For n = 1, we recapture from (2.8) the Ostrowski type inequalities

3. The Case of Two Points

The following proposition is a particular case of Corollary 1 for n = 2 and will
be considered in some details since there are important for applications.
Proposition 1. Let (X, k*k) be a Banach space with the Radon-Nikodym property
and f : [a, b] → X be an absolutely continuous function on [a, b] . If a ≤ x1 ≤ x2 ≤ b

4. The Case of Three Points
The case of three points is important for applications since it contains amongst
others Simpson's quadrature rule.
The following proposition holds:
Proposition 2. Let (X, k*k) be a Banach space with the Radon-Nikodym property
and f : [a, b] → X be an absolutely continuous function on [a, b] . If a ≤ x1 ≤ x2 ≤
